variant.question:
You have calculated point of no return (PNR) on a flight, having all negative WCs in the flight plan During the flight you experience that the W/V is stronger but coming from the same direction as in the flight plan
Consider the following statements

options.text: a recalculated PNR will move toward the place of departure.
the PNR will not change because the neither TAS nor fuel flow has changed.
you will arrive at the PNR at a later time than flight planned.
the PNR will, if recalculated, move toward the no-wind PNR.

variant.question:
Consider a Commercial Air Transport aeroplane flight. Which of the items listed below are the reasons given in the European regulations on Air Operations for conducting and recording fuel checks at regular intervals?
1. To compare actual consumption with planned consumption.
2. To check that the useable remaining fuel is sufficient to complete the flight.
3. To ensure dumping of excess fuel during the cruise that may otherwise result in exeeding the Maximum Landing Mass.
4. To determine the expected useable fuel remaining on arrival at the destination aerodrome.

For a flight departing from MSL at 3 663 lbs, 
cruising at FL80 at 2 300 RPM, 
20 ° C lean of peak EGT, 
in 40 kts headwind
calculate endurance

Before departure, the forecast is revised to a wind component of +15 kt. How much fuel is required in addition to the original calculation?

A commercial air transport flight is conducted in a jet aeroplane, with fuel checks performed approximately every 30 minutes. Route and Mach numbers are according to the planned figures. Fuel measurement is accurate to within +/-20 kg; fuel flowmeters show a constant 1 340 kg/h per engine. Explain the reason for creating the position “Waypoint 5 + 10 min”. - Waypoint ETO (UTC) ATO (UTC) Fuel (required) Fuel (actual) WPT 1 05:18 05:16 9 925 kg 10 170 kg WPT 2 05:48 05:46 8 590 kg 8 850 kg WPT 3 06:30 06:28 6 721 kg 6 930 kg WPT 4 07:02 07:00 5 297 kg 5 410 kg WPT 5 07:38 07:36 3 695 kg 3 700 kg WPT 5 + 10 min 07:46 3 225 kg 3 080 kg

options.text: Fuel flow appears to be increasing gradually. One way of verifying this is to create a waypoint based on time and use the last known rate of fuel consumption to reveal any trends.
The fuel flow can be confirmed to be different from the planned data. The flowmeters are indicating incorrect values and thrust can be reduced to match the planned fuel consumption.
Required fuel is more than actual fuel, but the fuel flow is verified as correct. This allows to conclude that the difference is due to the wind being different than planned.

Fuel flow appears to be reducing gradually. Should a revised fuel flow of 2 850 kg/h be verified by inclusion of this new waypoint, this would create the necessity to compute a revised landing fuel and landing mass.

variant.question: A commercial air transport flight is conducted in a jet aeroplane. Regular fuel checks are performed approximately every 30 minutes. Calculate the remaining endurance at waypoint Waypoint 5 + 10 min. - Waypoint ETO (UTC) ATO (UTC) Fuel (required) Fuel (actual) WPT 1 05:18 05:16 9 925 kg 10 170 kg WPT 2 05:48 05:46 8 590 kg 8 850 kg WPT 3 06:30 06:28 6 721 kg 6 930 kg WPT 4 07:02 06:58 5 297 kg 5 410 kg WPT 5 07:38 07:34 3 695 kg 3 800 kg
